Situation1: They handle a busy checkout with a long queue during peak hours.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: The line at my register snakes past the candy racks, customers shifting impatiently as I scan groceries and count change with practiced speed. My manager expects me to keep the line moving, no mistakes, especially now, during the after-work rush. I glance at the clock—almost closing time at the polling station. I’d planned to vote on my break, but the rush never let up. My phone buzzes: a reminder about the election. I finally dash over, only to be told by the official that my registration doesn’t match. If I want my vote to count, I have to fill out a provisional ballot form, and the station closes in ten minutes. The official’s voice is firm: I must follow every step, no shortcuts. My mind races—if I stay, the line at work will get even longer, and my manager will be furious. If I leave, I might lose my chance to vote. I feel torn, the weight of both roles pressing down, each demanding something I’m not sure I can give.
